meta.content: Synthesis of High Surface Area TiO2 Aerogel Support with Pt Nanoparticle Catalyst and CO Oxidation Study
meta.name: dc.title

meta.content: Catalysis Letters 2018 148:5
meta.name: dc.source

meta.content: 2018 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature
meta.name: dc.copyright

meta.content: We demonstrate the preparation and catalytic testing of nanocatalysts composed of TiO2 synthesized in aerogel using a supercritical drying process with Pt nanoparticles deposited on the mesopore oxide surface. By controlling the aging time, we found conditions that led to TiO2 with a surface area among the highest ever reported for a TiO2 material in aerogel form (~ 685 m2 g− 1). The chosen synthesis route also features good control over the pore volume and pore size. Even though our aerogel TiO2 support showed an amorphous structure before calcination, 90.2% anatase and 9.8% rutile phases co-existed after calcination at 500 °C for 2 h with an average particle size of about 17 nm based on XRD results. The as-synthesized TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 were both used as catalysts for the CO oxidation reaction. Uncalcined Pt/TiO2 showed 100% conversion at 300 °C. After calcination, Pt/TiO2 exhibited a significantly higher catalytic activity, showing 100% conversion at 125 °C and an activation energy of only 13.4 kcal mol− 1. We show that TiO2 synthesized by the aerogel method can be an excellent support material for nanocatalysis because of its high surface area and facile and scalable synthesis.

meta.content: Synthesis of High Surface Area TiO2 Aerogel Support with Pt Nanoparticle Catalyst and CO Oxidation Study - Catalysis Letters

Abstract We demonstrate the preparation and catalytic testing of nanocatalysts composed of TiO2 synthesized in aerogel using a supercritical drying process with Pt nanoparticles deposited on the mesopore oxide surface. By controlling the aging time, we found conditions that led to TiO2 with a surface area among the highest ever reported for a TiO2 material in aerogel form (~ 685 m2 g− 1). The chosen synthesis route also features good control over the pore volume and pore size. Even though our aerogel TiO2 support showed an amorphous structure before calcination, 90.2% anatase and 9.8% rutile phases co-existed after calcination at 500 °C for 2 h with an average particle size of about 17 nm based on XRD results. The as-synthesized TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 were both used as catalysts for the CO oxidation reaction. Uncalcined Pt/TiO2 showed 100% conversion at 300 °C. After calcination, Pt/TiO2 exhibited a significantly higher catalytic activity, showing 100% conversion at 125 °C and an activation energy of only 13.4 kcal mol− 1. We show that TiO2 synthesized by the aerogel method can be an excellent support material for nanocatalysis because of its high surface area and facile and scalable synthesis. Graphical Abstract

div.div:
Synthesis of High Surface Area TiO
2
Aerogel Support with Pt Nanoparticle Catalyst and CO Oxidation Study

header.h1:
Synthesis of High Surface Area TiO
2
Aerogel Support with Pt Nanoparticle Catalyst and CO Oxidation Study
header.p:
Catalysis Letters
volume
148
,
pages
1504–1513 (
2018
)
Cite this article

li.p:
814
Accesses

6
Citations

div.p:
We demonstrate the preparation and catalytic testing of nanocatalysts composed of TiO
2
synthesized in aerogel using a supercritical drying process with Pt nanoparticles deposited on the mesopore oxide surface. By controlling the aging time, we found conditions that led to TiO
2
with a surface area among the highest ever reported for a TiO
2
material in aerogel form (~ 685 m
2
g
− 1
). The chosen synthesis route also features good control over the pore volume and pore size. Even though our aerogel TiO
2
support showed an amorphous structure before calcination, 90.2% anatase and 9.8% rutile phases co-existed after calcination at 500 °C for 2 h with an average particle size of about 17 nm based on XRD results. The as-synthesized TiO
2
and Pt/TiO
2
were both used as catalysts for the CO oxidation reaction. Uncalcined Pt/TiO
2
showed 100% conversion at 300 °C. After calcination, Pt/TiO
2
exhibited a significantly higher catalytic activity, showing 100% conversion at 125 °C and an activation energy of only 13.4 kcal mol
− 1
. We show that TiO
2
synthesized by the aerogel method can be an excellent support material for nanocatalysis because of its high surface area and facile and scalable synthesis.

Much effort has gone into the synthesis of nanoparticles because of the unique combination of their physico-chemical properties. The size, shape, and composition of nanoparticles play significant roles in heterogeneous catalysis [
1
,
2
]. Nanoscale TiO
2
is a well-known material that is widely used in support materials for catalysis and photocatalysis because of the stability of its chemical structure [
3
,
4
], its physical and electrical properties [
5
,
6
], and its doping capability [
7
,
8
]. Of the three major crystallographic phases of TiO
2
(i.e. anatase, rutile, and brookite) [
9
], anatase TiO
2
has a tetragonal lattice structure and is widely used as a photocatalyst with UV excitation [
5
]. Rutile TiO
2
also has a tetragonal crystalline structure and is used in paints and varnishes, while brookite TiO
2
has an orthorhombic crystalline structure and is used in photocatalyst applications. Many researchers have focused on the synthesis of TiO
2
nanoparticles with large surface areas to improve performance because various applications are related to interfaces and thus dependent on high surface areas [
10
,
11
,
12
,
13
]. M. Choquette-Labbe et al. synthesized anatase TiO
2
nanoparticles with different particle sizes ranging from 10 to 32 nm, with the highest specific surface area of 131 m
2
g
− 1
. The activation energy for photocatalytic degradation increased from 12.5 to 15.8 kJ mol
− 1
as the surface area increased [
14
]. To synthesize TiO
2
nanoparticles with large surface area, many methods have been studied, including the sol–gel [
15
], hydrothermal [
16
], solvothermal [
17
], and chemical vapor deposition [
18
] methods.

The sol–gel method is a well-known and simple technique for synthesizing TiO
2
nanomaterials. The preparation involves hydrolysis and condensation of molecular precursor species resulting in gelation and strengthening of the gel by aging [
19
,
20
]. The method is simple and useful for controlling the desired nanoscale structure and morphology, which is the reason why it is widely used for many applications. Despite a great general interest in sol–gel preparation techniques, it generally leads to amorphous materials. When using evaporative drying from an organic solvent, materials are obtained with relatively low pore volumes and small mesopores. Supercritical drying of gels eliminates the formation of a three-phase boundary (i.e. a solid/liquid/gas interface) within the pores and minimizes structural collapse and densification of the gel structure [
21
], thus giving access to true aerogels with high pore volumes, typical pore sizes in the 15–50 nm range, and considerably higher surface areas. As it turns out, this combination of properties is key for heterogeneous catalysis applications; however, in the literature on TiO
2
catalyst supports, pure TiO
2
aerogel materials were generally accompanied by relatively low surface areas (i.e. typically below 200 m
2
g
− 1
). Baiker and coworkers pioneered this field in the late 1990s, but most of their work focused on mixed TiO
2
/MO
x
metal oxide systems, where surface areas > 600 m
2
g
− 1
were more readily obtained [
22
].

Here, we demonstrate the synthesis of Pt/TiO
2
aerogel model catalyst systems with high surface area using an optimized synthetic procedure for the TiO
2
aerogel. The effects of aging time and the mode of the addition of the acid during the TiO
2
gel preparation step were studied to better control pore morphology and the physical properties of the TiO
2
. In parallel, gels containing separately synthesized Pt nanoparticles were prepared and converted into corresponding Pt/TiO
2
aerogels. The catalytic activities of both types of materials were tested using the CO oxidation benchmark reaction.

div.h3:
Synthesis of Platinum Nanoparticles and TiO
2
Aerogels
div.p:
Chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate, sodium hydroxide, and ethylene glycol were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Methanol was purchased from Fluka, nitric acid (65 wt%) from Merck, and titanium(IV) butoxide (TB) from Alpha Products. Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) with an average molecular weight of 40,000 g mol
−1
was purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Supercritical CO
2
drying of the TiO
2
gel samples was carried out in a 2 l autoclave (Separex SA, France). Envelope densities were measured on the supercritically dried monolithic fragments using an envelope density device (AccuPyc II 1340, Micromeritics, US). The platinum nanoparticles were prepared according to Rioux’s method [
23
]. The synthesis was tailored to obtain platinum nanoparticles ~ 1.7 nm in size. In a typical experiment, 0.25 g (0.48 mmol) of chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate was dissolved in 12.5 ml (0.225 mol) of ethylene glycol. This solution was then added to an identical volume of 0.5 M NaOH solution in ethylene glycol. The mixture was heated to 160 °C in an oil bath and stirred with nitrogen bubbling. After 20 min, the color of the solution started to change from orange to dark brown/black. The reaction mixture was allowed to react for a total of 3 h, after which the particles were precipitated by adding 1 ml of a 2 M aqueous HCl solution. After centrifugation, the nanoparticles were suspended in 15 ml of a solution containing 12.2 mg PVP (0.3 µmol) in methanol. The TiO
2
aerogels were prepared according to a modified version of Schneider’s and Campbell’s methods [
24
,
25
]. In Schneider’s method, the molar ratio of water, tert-butoxy-titanium(IV), and acid was 4.1:1:0.08 and the mesoporous TiO
2
showed a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of around 200 m
2
g
− 1
after calcining at 350 °C under air. Campbella et al. investigated the effect of different solvent systems and the water-to-Ti-alkoxide ratio [
25
]. They found that the highest surface area TiO
2
aerogels (200 m
2
g
− 1
) are obtained by a roughly stoichiometric water addition (i.e. a ratio of 4:1 after calcination at 500 °C for 2 h). In this work, to enhance the surface area of the TiO
2
, the amount of acid and water added varied from those recipes.

For all the experiments, two solutions were prepared: (1) Solution A consisting of 15 ml of methanol (370 mmol) and 4.3 ml of TB (12.6 mmol), prepared under nitrogen; and (2) Solution B consisting of 3.75 ml of methanol (90 mmol) and 1.8 ml of purified water (100 mmol). 0.125 ml (1.8 mmol) of concentrated nitric acid was added to either Solution A or Solution B. After stirring the respective solutions for 10 min, Solution B was added via a dropping funnel to Solution A in a sealed three-neck round-bottom flask, while purging with nitrogen, and the final mixture was then vigorously stirred. To prepare TiO
2
aerogels containing Pt nanoparticles, the methanol in Solution A was replaced with the same volume of a solution of methanol and Pt nanoparticles, as prepared in the previous section at 10% v/v loading. The samples were aged for between 1 and 3 days, according to the details given in Table
1
(TiO
2
-3D-TB, TiO
2
-3D, TiO
2
-2D, Pt/TiO
2
-2D, Pt/TiO
2
-1D), prior to supercritical drying. During aging, the samples were kept in a sealed container and the solution was exchanged daily to remove residual water and reaction by-products. For supercritical drying, the aged gels were placed inside the autoclave and the methanol pore fluid was replaced with liquid CO
2
for 24 h at ambient temperature. The autoclave temperature was then raised to 45 °C so that the internal pressure reached 150 bar. Finally, the vessel was depressurized at 70 bar h
− 1
. The experimental conditions are summarized in Table
1
.

figcaption.b:
Table 1 Summary of the TiO
2
and Pt/TiO
2
samples with different aerogels and experimental conditions

div.p:
X-ray diffraction (XRD, D-MAX 2500, Rigaku) analysis was used with nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation with a scanning speed of 6° min
−1
and 20° to 80° of 2θ. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tiatan cubed G2 60-300) was used to visualize the TiO
2
and Pt nanoparticles and measure their respective feature sizes. The oxidation states and surface chemical composition of the Pt nanoparticles supported on the TiO
2
aerogel were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy before and after the CO oxidation reaction test with Al Kα as the X-ray source (1486.6 eV) under ultra-high vacuum (10
− 10
Torr). To measure the pore size, pore volume, and BET surface area of the samples, nitrogen adsorption was carried out using a gas-sorption system (CELSORP-max) at 77 K. The BET surface area was calculated from the sorption isotherm in the relative pressure range from 0.05 to 0.2 by assuming a cross-sectional area of 0.162 nm
2
for the N
2
molecules [
26
]. The metal dispersion of the Pt nanoparticles on TiO
2
was measured using CO pulse chemisorption (BELCAT-B: BEL Japan Inc.) with a thermal conductivity detector. 50 mg of catalyst was pretreated under H
2
(50 sccm) at 250 °C for 20 min. The temperature was cooled to 50 °C. Then, 10% CO/He was introduced as gas pulses until the area became stable. The metal dispersion was calculated by assuming a chemisorption stoichiometry of Pt/CO = 1.

In this study, both Pt-loaded and neat TiO
2
aerogels were used as model catalysts for CO oxidation. For catalyst testing, 100 mg of a sample was supported on quartz wool and placed inside a quartz reactor. A K-type thermocouple was placed above the catalyst to monitor and control the temperature of the catalyst bed. All gases were controlled by mass flow controllers (Brooks) that had been previously calibrated at 25 °C and 1 atm. The gas hourly space velocity was kept constant at 6000 h
− 1
and the test gas was composed of 4% CO, 10% O
2
, and balanced with He. The TiO
2
aerogel model catalysts were pretreated at 250 °C for one hour under reducing conditions (4% hydrogen). The cell was then cooled down to room temperature. Once the reaction gases reached a steady flow, the temperature was raised to 250 °C. The gas composition after the catalytic cell was monitored every 5 min using gas chromatography (IGC 7200, DS SCIENCE) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The CO oxidation reaction was carried out starting at room temperature until the CO conversion showed 100%. The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated from the number of CO molecules reacted per mole of active metal (Pt) per second [
27
,
28
].

Figure
1
shows the XRD pattern of the TiO
2
aerogel before and after calcination at 500 °C for 2 h as well as the Pt/TiO
2
model catalyst after calcination. L.K. Campbell et al. synthesized aerogel TiO
2
and showed XRD results following heat treatment at different temperatures [
25
]. The pure anatase phase of TiO
2
was obtained at 500 °C and the rutile phase was formed at the above temperature (600 °C). It is widely known that the anatase phase of TiO
2
is much more active than the rutile phase. Therefore, we calcined the TiO
2
at 500 °C to make the anatase phase the dominant phase. The uncalcined TiO
2
particles showed a broad line from 20° to 38.2° in 2θ space, which implies that the TiO
2
has a highly amorphous structure. Comparing the XRD results of the uncalcined TiO
2
, the XRD pattern of the TiO
2
after calcination showed several peaks from 20° to 80° of 2θ. The peaks at 25.3°, 37.9°, 48.1°, 55.0°, 62.7°, 68.9°, 70.2° and 75.1° imply the anatase phase of TiO
2
; the other peaks originate from the rutile phase of TiO
2
[
29
,
30
]. Thermodynamically, the anatase phase is more stable compared with the rutile phase and is widely used as a catalyst because oxygen species can easily move in the anatase phase [
31
,
32
]. From the equation
f
r
= 1.26
I
r
/(
I
a
+ 1.26
I
r
), the mass fraction of the aerogel TiO
2
was calculated using the intensities of the (1 1 0) and (1 0 1) reflections for the rutile and anatase peaks, respectively [
33
,
34
]. In the equation,
I
r
, and
I
a
are the intensities of the rutile and anatase phases, respectively. The mass fraction of the anatase phase was 90.8%. Because of the anatase phase of TiO
2
, we could expect the anatase aerogel TiO
2
to show higher activity in the CO oxidation reaction. The Pt/TiO
2
material did not show any noticeable Pt-related signatures, which means that the Pt phase was well distributed inside the TiO
2
support; very small nanoparticles give rise to very broad peaks according to Scherer’s equation, which in this case are indistinguishable from the background signal.

XRD patterns of the aerogel TiO
2
(TiO
2
-2D) before and after calcination and the Pt/TiO
2
(Pt/TiO
2
-2D) after calcination

Figure
2
a shows a TEM image of the aerogel TiO
2
. From the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of the aerogel TiO
2
(Fig.
2
b), the lattice fringe with an interlayer distance of 0.34 nm is clearly visible. This value corresponds to the structure of the anatase phase of TiO
2
(101). Figure
2
c shows a TEM image of the Pt/TiO
2
particles with the particle size distribution shown in the inset for the Pt-loaded sample. The particle size distribution was obtained by measuring the diameter of ~ 100 particles in the TEM images for both the TiO
2
and Pt nanophases. The geometric mean diameter of the aerogel TiO
2
particles was 16.7 ± 2.6 nm. The Pt nanoparticles are shown as a dark contrast to the TiO
2
particles; thus, the Pt nanoparticles were well distributed on the TiO
2
surface. The average diameter of the Pt particles was 2.95 ± 0.83 nm. This is significantly larger than the average size of the starting materials of 1.7 nm and could be linked to a morphological change of the particles upon adsorption onto the TiO
2
surface, which is also commonly observed in silica/noble metal catalysts. Figure
2
d shows a HRTEM image of the circular area in Fig.
2
c, which shows an interlayer distance of 0.25 nm and is consistent with the (111) lattice plane of Pt.

TEM images of the aerogel TiO
2
(TiO
2
-2D) and Pt/TiO
2
(Pt/TiO
2
-2D) samples.
a
Aerogel TiO
2
after calcination and
b
HRTEM image of the area in the circle in (
a
).
c
Pt/TiO
2
after calcination with inset showing the size distribution of the Pt nanoparticles.
d
HRTEM image of the area in the circle in (
c
)

The results of physical properties are shown in Fig.
3
. Generally, pH and aging time are major factors that can affect physical properties during aerogel synthesis [
24
,
25
,
35
]. The highest surface area could occur when using an optimal amount of acid because higher acid content hinders kinetic condensation, which forms branched soft gels, whereas weak gels are formed with low acid content. Therefore, a gel network that is not strengthened can collapse during the processing steps. In case of TiO
2
, the BET surface area increased as the amount of acid increased until reaching a HNO
3
/Ti ratio of 0.02; the surface area stabilized above this ratio. Furthermore, during the aging process, the gel can be strengthened and stabilized to restrict shrinkage of the gel network and maintain a higher surface area [
36
]. M. Schneider synthesized an aerogel TiO
2
showing a surface area of ~ 200 m
2
g
− 1
with less than 1 day of aging time [
24
]. We changed aging time in this study to longer than 1 day [1 day(1D), 2 days (2D), 3 days (3D)] to determine the effect on the physical properties. Before controlling the aging time, we varied the mode of acid addition. Nitric acid was introduced into either Solution A (TiO
2
-3D-TB) or Solution B (TiO
2
-3D) with the same aging time (3 days). Even though the TiO
2
-3D-TB showed a higher surface area, we expect that both samples have large enough surface areas as catalysts. However, TiO
2
with larger pore volume and pore size could be obtained with the TiO
2
-3D. In catalysis, the diffusion of reactant gas molecules into the pores is a major factor. Most of the TiO
2
aerogels (i.e. TiO
2
-3D-TB, TiO
2
-3D, TiO
2
-2D), and Pt/TiO
2
-2D (not shown) exhibit type IV adsorption–desorption isotherms, which are typical for aerogels with mesoporous structure [
37
]. However, the aerogel that was synthesized with only 1 day of aging (Pt/TiO
2
-1D) showed more of a type I adsorption–desorption isotherm, indicating that the particles have less mesoporosity compared with the other aerogels. Therefore, we believe that under the given conditions, aging for 1 day was insufficient to strengthen the gel network enough to remain stable during the subsequent processing steps of solvent exchange and supercritical drying. As a result, the pore structure collapsed to a large extent and the densified material became primarily microporous. This is also nicely seen in the pore size distribution insets for the different aerogel samples. The BET surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter of the different TiO
2
aerogels are summarized in Table
2
. When comparing the surface area of the TiO
2
aerogels in this study with those obtained by Schneider’s method (i.e. ~ 200 m
2
g
− 1
), our materials exhibit specific surface areas up to three times higher. In the literature, there are also more recent studies describing the preparation of TiO
2
aerogels [
38
,
39
,
40
,
41
]. One of the highest surface areas found for pure TiO
2
aerogel materials is 495 m
2
g
− 1
, reported by Yang et al. [
38
]. Here, we were able to increase this value to 685.2 m
2
g
− 1
, about 40% higher.

Nitrogen adsorption and desorption properties of
a
TiO
2
-3D-TB,
b
TiO
2
-3D,
c
TiO
2
-2D, and
d
Pt/TiO
2
-1D. Desorption and adsorption curves are shown with red and black lines, respectively. Insets are the pore size distributions for each sample

figcaption.b:
Table 2 Summary of the physical properties of the TiO
2
and Pt/TiO
2
samples

div.p:
Aging time is clearly a key factor for making high-quality TiO
2
aerogels. Aging depends on several process parameters, including solvent composition, temperature, and acid catalyst concentration. Under the given experimental conditions (i.e. pH, solvent system, and temperature), 3 days of aging were necessary to prepare TiO
2
with a large pore size and pore volume. However, the procedure used here has not been optimized for manufacturing, where such long aging times are undesirable. Optimization of the preparation for a more scalable process with < 12 h of aging time is currently ongoing and will be presented in a follow-up publication.

Figure
4
shows XPS element window spectra for Pt 4f before and after catalyst testing. Both results show primarily metallic Pt
0
peaks and two higher oxidation states of Pt. In general, the metallic Pt peak occurs at a binding energy of 71.2 eV with Pt4f
7/2
and oxidized Pt peaks occurring at 72.40 eV for Pt
2+
and 74.20 eV for Pt
4+
[
42
]. Before the reaction, the metallic Pt species fraction was 0.67 and remained more or less unchanged after the reaction (i.e. 0.63). It is widely known that Pt metals with only traces of Pt
2+
and Pt
4+
are highly active for the CO oxidation reaction. Therefore, to increase the Pt
0
ratio, the catalyst was reduced under H
2
before the CO oxidation reaction. After the reaction, the ratio of Pt
2+
/Pt
0
changed from 0.14 to 0.35. This is understandable because the metallic Pt was partly oxidized during the reaction.

XPS data of the Pt/TiO
2
(Pt/TiO
2
-2D) samples
a
before and
b
after the CO oxidation reaction

To demonstrate the role of the Pt nanoparticles as the active material, we measured the catalytic activity of neat TiO
2
aerogel and the Pt/TiO
2
aerogel system with increasing temperature, namely from room temperature to 350 °C (Fig.
5
a). In general, the most accepted mechanism for CO oxidation with a Pt catalyst is the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism [
43
,
44
,
45
,
46
,
47
,
48
]. In this mechanism, the CO could adsorb on the Pt surface, which then reacts with an oxygen atom dissociated on the metallic Pt surface to produce CO
2
. Below the ignition temperature, the adsorbed CO is too stable to restrict the dissociation of an oxygen molecule on the Pt surface. Therefore, CO
2
could not be produced. However, above the ignition temperature, CO coverage on the Pt surfaces is reduced, which allows the dissociation of O
2
. Newton et al. showed an ignition temperature of 127 °C for the CO oxidation reaction with a Pt-Al
2
O
3
catalyst [
49
].The highest surface area sample, TiO
2
-3D-TB, showed 0% CO conversion at ~ 200 °C; the conversion then increased linearly as the temperature increased to 350 °C. This is a thermal and not a catalytic effect because, in general, TiO
2
showed no reduction peaks with temperature-programmed reduction up to temperatures of 800 °C under hydrogen gas [
50
,
51
]. The same trend was also observed with TiO
2
-3D; however, the conversion was slightly higher than that of TiO
2
-3D-TB. Even though the surface area of the TiO
2
-3D-TB was higher than that of the TiO
2
-3D, we believe that the larger pore volume and pore size of the TiO
2
-3D allowed the gas to diffuse more readily, thus resulting in a higher conversion. The CO conversion of the Pt/TiO
2
-2D was very small at 200 °C; it slowly increased linearly up to 280 °C, and then rose very rapidly to 100% CO conversion around 300 °C. There are two reasons that the catalytic activity of the Pt/TiO
2
was enhanced compared with pure TiO
2
without calcination: First, Pt particles on the TiO
2
might be partly oxidized to form PtO (i.e. an active site for catalysis) by oxygen in the reactant gas during the reaction. Second, the onset of nanoscale phase transformation of the amorphous TiO
2
to crystalline TiO
2
occurs in this temperature range. Therefore, we could expect that pre-treatment would enhance catalytic performance. More detailed work will be needed to separate those individual contributions. However, the Pt/TiO
2
-2D showed enhanced catalytic activity after calcination (Fig.
5
b). 0% CO conversion was maintained at 90 °C and the conversion increased linearly up to ~ 40% at 120 °C. 100% conversion was obtained at 125 °C. This occurred because, as we mentioned above, the amorphous phase of the TiO
2
could be transferred to the anatase (dominant) phase of the TiO
2
after calcination, which is also widely known as an active catalytic phase [
52
]. Kim et al. synthesized ~ 2 nm of Pt on TiO
2
by arc plasma deposition, and the BET surface area was 75.2 m
2
g
−1
. In this paper, they also used this catalyst for the CO oxidation reaction. They obtained 100% CO conversion at ~ 165 °C. Comparing these results, we could expect that the enhanced catalytic activity using the Pt/TiO
2
prepared by the aerogel method in this study is the result of the high surface area [
27
].

Catalytic activity for CO oxidation of the
a
aerogel TiO
2
(TiO
2
-3D-TB, TiO
2
-3D) and Pt/TiO
2
(Pt/TiO
2
-2D) before calcination and
b
after calcination of Pt/TiO
2
(Pt/TiO2-2D)

In general, the catalyst with high surface area shows higher catalytic activity if the support itself is only used as catalyst because the surface area is the active site. However, if a metal is deposited on the support, the reaction occurs on the metal surface because the metal is much more active than the support. The high surface area could then assist in uniformly dispersing the metal on the surface. Therefore, the metal on support with high surface area could show enhanced catalytic activity. Figure
6
a shows the catalytic activity of the CO oxidation reaction with the Pt/TiO
2
-2D catalyst after calcination. The turnover frequencies (TOF) were measured in units of reacted CO per metal Pt surface site per second of reaction time. The metal dispersion calculated from CO chemisorption was 9.3%. The TOF increased linearly from 0.27 to 0.84 s
− 1
with increasing temperature and increased rapidly starting at 125 °C to a TOF of 1.93 s
− 1
. The Arrhenius plot is shown in Fig.
6
b and the slope was calculated from the results before the ignition temperature (i.e. 125 °C). From the slope, the apparent activation energy of the reaction was calculated to be 13.4 ± 1.4 kcal mol
− 1
(56.1 ± 5.86 kJ mol
− 1
). The literature reports [
53
] that activation energies for Pt/SiO
2
and Pt/Al
2
O
3
were 3–5 and 16–22 kcal mol
− 1
, respectively. With Pt/TiO
2
, the activation energy varied from 10 to 14 kcal mol
− 1
, depending on the size of the Pt nanoparticles, preparation methods, and diversity of the reaction pathways in the reactions [
54
]. The synthesis of TiO
2
with a high surface area using the aerogel method is quite facile, and large-scale synthesis is relatively straightforward, which may also have intriguing applications in photocatalysis. Our results demonstrate that pure TiO
2
aerogels can be an excellent support material for noble metal nanoparticle catalysis.

Catalytic activity for CO oxidation of the aerogel Pt nanoparticles on Pt/TiO
2
(Pt/TiO
2
-2D) after calcination.
a
Turnover frequency with temperature and
b
Arrhenius plot

In this study, we successfully synthesized TiO
2
aerogels with a surface area of 685 m
2
g
− 1
, which is the highest surface area found in the literature for any pure TiO
2
aerogel material. Pore volume and pore size could be controlled to some extent by varying the aging time and mode of addition of the acid during gel preparation. After calcining at 500 °C for 2 h, amorphous TiO
2
was transformed to crystalline TiO
2
with the anatase phase as the dominant phase. Integration of 1.7 nm Pt nanoparticles into the synthesis led to presumably flattened 2.95 nm Pt nanoplatelets on the TiO
2
surface. The as-synthesized TiO
2
and Pt/TiO
2
were used as catalysts for the CO oxidation reaction. To confirm the calcination effect, the catalytic activity of uncalcined TiO
2
and Pt/TiO
2
were measured. The uncalcined TiO
2
showed a linearly increasing CO conversion up to ~ 30%, and the Pt/TiO
2
showed 100% CO conversion above 300 °C. The Pt/TiO
2
with high surface area showed enhanced catalytic activity (100% conversion at 125 °C) compared with the that in the literature showing low surface area (100% conversion at 165 °C). Pt nanoparticles on the aerogel TiO
2
showed an activation energy of 13.4 kcal mol
− 1
for the CO oxidation reaction.
